title: 103_s2302
content: The Act is titled the "Old San Francisco Mint Commemorative Coin Act" and specifies the coin details. The "Old San Francisco Mint Commemorative Coin Act" authorizes the minting of $1 silver coins and half dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. These coins are legal tender as per section 5103 of title 31, United States Code. All coins minted under the "Old San Francisco Mint Commemorative Coin Act" are considered numismatic items under section 5134 of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary will only obtain silver for minting coins from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of the coins will be determined under this Act. The design of the coins minted under this Act will be emblematic of the Old San Francisco Mint, its role in gold coinage, and the educational mission of the Old San Francisco Mint Museum. Each coin will have a value designation, the year "1995" inscribed, and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with Friends of the Mint and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The term "Friends of the Mint" is defined as The Old Mint Corporation, a nonprofit organization incorporated in California in 1994. This definition is used in the Act and was reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at the US Mint facility in San Francisco with the "S" mark. The Secretary may mint coins only from January 1, 1995, to December 31, 1995. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. Surcharges of $10 per coin for the $1 coin will be included in all sales. The $1 coin will be sold at $10 per coin, and the half dollar coin will be sold at $2 per coin. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales will be paid to Friends of the Mint for refurbishing and maintaining the Old San Francisco Mint. The Comptroller General can audit the expenditures. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure no net cost to the Government for minting coins. Payment for coins requires full payment, security, or a guarantee. SEC. 10. REPORT TO CONGRESS. The Secretary must provide semiannual reports to Congress on activities under this Act.
